awd_titl_txt: REGULATION OF CAP-INDEPENDENT TRANSLATION IN PLUS-STRAND RNA VIRUSES
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will benefit society by having college undergraduates, PhD level graduate students and postdoctoral researchers participate in research designed to address how viruses engage in one of their most important activities, synthesis of their required proteins.  This research will be presented at scientific conferences, used in the teaching of introduction to biology for biology majors, and used to introduce undergraduates at the University of Maryland and Bowie State University to cutting edge procedures designed to study how the virus manipulates its genome in ways that were not previously thought to occur.  In addition, this research adds a new dimension of understanding to a procedure (protein synthesis) that was thought to be mostly solved by exploring the possible regulation of a key aspect of virus biology: how they switch from being a template for making proteins to having that template replicated by changing how the template interacts with specific proteins.  By studying three different viruses that all appear to use the same process to control how proteins are made, results should have a broad impact on virus research in general. Thus the results of this research should be applicable not only to plant viruses, but also animal and human viruses, including ones that cause serious disease in animals and plants.  

Recent results have led to the hypothesis that translation enhancers located in 3' UTRs of plant viruses need to be cleared of bound translation factors/ribosomes for replication of the template to proceed.  PEMV contains three 3'cap-independent translation enhancers (3'CITEs): kl-TSS, PTE, and TSS, only two of which are used by the genomic RNA (kl-TSS/PTE) while all three are used by the subgenomic RNA.  In Aim 1, SHAPE RNA structure probing and mutagenesis will be used to determine whether a sequence exclusive to the gRNA alters the structure of the TSS to keep it from functioning.  In Aim 2, compensatory mutations and SHAPE will be used to examine a newly discovered element (the CAS) for its ability to block translation factor binding to downstream 3' CITEs in three viruses.   The newly identified replication element DUO will also be investigated for interaction with CAS during translation, allowing the critical kl-H hairpin to bind CAS, keeping CAS from binding to the downstream 3'CITE and interfering with translation factor binding. Aim 3 will employ mutagenesis, SHAPE and EMSA to determine if CAS interacts with, and destabilizes its downstream 3'CITE, and whether this interferes with binding of translation factors and RdRp transcription. Aim 4 will investigate the relationship among DUO, kl-H and CAS to determine how CAS is blocked from binding its 3'CITE.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A major activity of all viruses is the translating of their genomes into protein products required for infection. To understand translation of RNA viruses, it is essential to elucidate the overall structure of dynamic RNA genomes, a complicated process that requires multiple different versions of a virus to find structures that are conserved.  For many plant RNA viruses, RNA structures located near their 3? ends are critical for normal protein synthesis. Additionally, the ribosome protein synthesizing machines occasionally continue past specific termination sites known as frameshifting sites to expand the length of particular protein products.  This grant was awarded to study translation of very simple plant RNA viruses, carmoviruses and umbraviruses, as models that can be used by other investigators to examine other viruses for similar features.  Additional novel structures were discovered upstream of well-studied translation elements that were critical for translation of both virus groups and structural approaches were used to determine how they impacted known translation elements. One umbravirus multifunctional protein known for its property of supporting virus movement was also found to protect the virus against nonsense-mediated decay, a process that degrades viruses (or cellular mRNAs) with long 3? untranslated regions.  To validate results, additional umbraviruses and carmoviruses were examined, leading to the seminal observation that an umbra-like virus discovered in California and added to the GenBank database in 2011 was a novel, full-length subviral RNA and not a truncated umbravirus as the CA investigators thought.  This discovery led to searches for other similar umbra-like RNAs (ulaRNAs) in the database and many more were found, leading to their division into three classes.  The one examined in detail for this award, CYVaV, which only encodes its replication-required polymerase protein (it has lost the ability to make a movement protein, which other Class 2 ulaRNAs continue to make), had numerous features found in no other virus or virus-like RNA.  These novel features include the use of host proteins for movement, an extensive host-range including citrus and grapevine, a novel 3? translation structure, astonishingly high frameshifting rate (30%, normally 1-5%), and symptoms on a laboratory host that are unique to plant viruses (truncation, extended life, multiple leaves emerging from each node).  To fully investigate CYVaV, its 2-D structure was solved, requiring the development of an RNA structure drawing program (RNAcanvas) that is now in use by investigators throughout the world.  Solving the structure of CYVaV led to the determination that the frameshifting site involved numerous alternative structures that spanned portions of over 2000 bases.  An additional finding, relevant to most (all?) RNA viruses was that small changes to the ulaRNA genome (single nucleotide changes in loops of hairpin structures or small sequence insertions) led to massive changes in the flexibility of nucleotides throughout the genome.

The realization that CYVaV could serve as a vector for delivery of small RNAs into plants, the ?Holy Grail? of plant protection against pathogens, led to a number of broader impacts including the founding of the Biotech company Silvec Biologics (12 current employees), which is developing CYVaV and related ulaRNAs to combat diseases of trees and vines for which there are currently no cures or treatments.  An additional important discovery with broad implications, was the discovery of how to make virus vectors stable when additional RNA structures are added.  All of these findings led to one provisional patent, 13 published papers, two submitted papers, and two papers in preparation.
